courseTitle: Introductory Astronomy of the Solar System
courseDescription: A study of the physical principles and scientific investigation of objects in our solar system. Emphasis on how we acquire knowledge of celestial objects to develop models of our universe.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using software like Stellarium or Celestia
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting scientific findings to a non-technical audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the validity of scientific models

courseTitle: Introductory Astronomy of Galaxies and Cosmology
courseDescription: Emphasizes the study of stars, star systems, cosmology and relativity. Emphasis on how we acquire knowledge of celestial objects to develop models of our universe.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on astronomical topics

courseDescription: An introductory laboratory course in astronomy dealing with experiments about the laws of nature that apply to objects in our solar system. This course is intended for students with previous transfer credit for an Introductory Astronomy of the Solar System Lecture course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding laws of nature in astronomy
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with lab partners on experiments
Presenting findings from experiments to peers
Effective communication of experimental procedures and results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying scientific method to experimental design
Analyzing data to draw conclusions about solar system objects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group experiments and data collection
Taking initiative in experimental setup and execution
Leading group discussions on experimental findings

courseDescription: A laboratory course in astronomy dealing with experiments about the laws of nature that apply to galaxies and the cosmos as a whole. This course is intended for students with previous transfer credit for an Introductory Astronomy of Stars, Galaxies and the Cosmos Lecture course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting findings to peers and instructors
Effective communication of complex astronomical concepts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group projects in the lab setting
Providing guidance to peers during experiments

courseTitle: Honors: Introductory Astronomy of the Solar System
courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College. A special honors version of ASTP 103N.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting scientific findings to a non-technical audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing hypotheses based on astronomical evidence
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on astronomical topics
Coordinating research efforts within a team

courseTitle: Honors: Introductory Astronomy of Galaxies and Cosmology
courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College. A special honors version of ASTP 104N.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in interpreting astronomical data

courseDescription: A one-semester course covering the important topics of modern astrophysics. The elementary physical basis of stellar structure and evolution is derived from first principles. Theoretical and observational details of white dwarfs, neutron stars, pulsars, and black holes are developed. Elements of Big Bang cosmology are also presented.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Deriving stellar evolution equations from first principles
Analyzing observational data of celestial objects
Applying theoretical concepts to practical astrophysical scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on astrophysical topics

courseDescription: Observational techniques in astronomy with emphasis on constellation identification, celestial movements, and telescopic observation.  Individualized night observations are required.

A course in astronomy dealing with stars and stellar systems. Topics will include observational astronomy, the electromagnetic spectrum, relativity, stellar and galactic structures, cosmology, and the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis and interpretation in astronomy
Knowledge of stellar and galactic structures
Exploring methods for the search for extraterrestrial intelligence
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating group discussions on astronomy topics
Collaborating with other educators on astronomy lesson plans
Engaging students in hands-on astronomical activities
Presenting astronomical information in an engaging manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in evaluating astronomical theories
Applying mathematical concepts to astronomical problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Motivating students to explore astronomy further
Providing guidance on career paths in astronomy

courseDescription: Introduction to special and general relativity and cosmology. The course covers the current understanding of the structure and evolution of the Universe. The most important unsolved cosmological problems will be discussed, as well as current efforts/theories that may lead to the solution. Special and general relativity, Einstein's field equations, Friedmann-Lemaitre-Robertson-Walker metric, Friedmann’s equations, Schwarzschild solution and black holes, Big Bang, cosmic microwave background radiation, dark matter and dark energy are covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of special and general relativity
Understanding of Schwarzschild solution and black holes
Interpretation of cosmic microwave background radiation
Knowledge of dark matter and dark energy theories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of complex cosmological concepts with peers
Presentation of cosmological theories and solutions
Engagement in group discussions regarding unsolved cosmological problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of current efforts and theories in cosmology
Problem-solving in the context of unresolved cosmological issues

courseDescription: In-depth study of a selected topic in astrophysics at the advanced undergraduate level. May include a laboratory or computational component.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using Python or R
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing mathematical models for astrophysical phenomena

courseDescription: Observational techniques in astronomy with emphasis on constellation identification, celestial movements, and telescopic observation.  Individualized night observations are required.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordinating night observation sessions
Time management for night sky observations

courseDescription: A course in astronomy dealing with stars and stellar systems. Topics will include observational astronomy, the electromagnetic spectrum, relativity, stellar and galactic structures, cosmology, and the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex astronomical concepts to students
Facilitating group discussions on astronomy topics
Collaborating with other teachers on astronomy lesson plans
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing observational data for astronomical research
Developing creative teaching strategies for astronomy concepts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading astronomy-related projects in the classroom
Organizing astronomy field trips or stargazing events for students
Managing resources for astronomy education initiatives

courseDescription: In-depth study of a selected topic in astrophysics at the introductory graduate level. May include a laboratory or computational component.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using Python or MATLAB
